image.altText: A man wearing a dark jacket and sunglasses.

items.synopsis: Three men involved in a failed housing scheme which targeted elderly customers appear in a Perth court for allegedly breaching corporate law.

title.children: Architects of failed housing scheme impacting retirees across the nation face court on criminal charges

image.altText: a woman in a burka amid tents

items.synopsis: The charity Save the Children had launched a case in the Federal Court, on behalf of 20 children and 11 women stuck in the Al-Roj camp in the north of the war ravaged country

title.children: Women and children stranded in Syria receive 'gut-wrenching' court dismissal

image.altText: A man in high-vis posing for a selfie

items.synopsis: A 38-year-old man pleads guilty to kidnapping a young girl as she walked to school, an act that triggered a frantic search for her in Perth's southern suburbs.

title.children: Man admits kidnapping 9yo girl as she walked to school in Perth's south

image.altText: L-R: Lachlan Gillespie, Tsehay Hawkins, Simon Pryce, Anthony Field

items.synopsis: Bunbury's mayor says he will review the council's approach to rough sleepers, after it played Hot Potato on loop to drive them away, sparking a public outcry.

title.children: City stops playing Wiggles music to deter homeless people after 'disappointed' band speaks out

image.altText: Aerial shot of smoke with the top of a city building in the foreground

items.synopsis: Police charge a 41-year-old man who they allege deliberately lit a series of bushfires in central Perth and Kings Park, including one that threatened high-rise apartments near the popular Jacob's Ladder staircase.

title.children: Arson charges laid against man over fires that tore through bushland in Perth and Kings Park

image.altText: A red stage with Qantas logo on projector

items.synopsis: Qantas has received its first strike from shareholders at its AGM, days after defending itself from "ghost flight" allegations, while the ASX closed higher for the week after Wall Street rallied overnight.

title.children: Qantas board on notice after 83pc protest vote by shareholders over executive pay, ASX closes higher — as it happened

image.altText: A court sketch of Erin Patterson.

items.synopsis: Prosecutors say it will take months to analyse computer equipment seized from the home of a woman charged with murder over a mushroom meal linked to three deaths in Victoria's east.

title.children: Erin Patterson faces court after police lay murder charges over mushroom meal

image.altText: Vanessa Hudson addresses the media

items.synopsis: A change in leadership at Qantas and the ACCC has led to more of the same from both, which is a looming disaster for the airline and a credit to the regulator, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Vanessa Hudson torches last sliver of goodwill defending 'ghost flights'

image.altText: A portrait of Amber Jess Millar smiling and wearing a flower crown

items.synopsis: A WA Coroner says he has determined he has enough evidence to make a finding without an inquest.

title.children: Coroner says inquest into 12-year-old girl's death in Kimberley chopper crash 'not desirable'

image.altText: A bench under a tree in a city park, with buildings and traffic lights in the background.

items.synopsis: Vulnerable Perth women forced to sleep rough will have one less option for help at the end of the month, as a safe space at a community centre that had been sheltering them is forced to close.

title.children: Sleeping on the streets is hard enough, let alone for women. Soon they'll have one less safe place to go

image.altText: Former Israeli PM defends civilian casualities in Gaza

items.synopsis: Seven United Nations special rapporteurs issue a warning about the risk of genocide, but Israel says it is aiming its attacks at Hamas not civilians. Follow live.

title.children: Israeli opposition leader blames Hamas as UN raises risk of Palestinian genocide

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two more people supported by the Australian government have been able to leave Gaza, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFA) says. This brings the total of people helped out of Gaza by the Australian government to 25. Yesterday it confirmed 20 Australians safely fled the strip, as well as a permanent resident and two family members. It is not known whether the two who left in the past 24 hours are citizens. A DFAT spokesperson told the ABC it was still assisting 64 individuals in Gaza, composed of Australians and their families, who have requested help to depart. "We continue to engage closely with partners in the region to ensure the remaining Australians in Gaza who wish to leave are able to do so as soon as possible," they said. "Departures depend on a range of factors, and the situation in Gaza remains highlight challenging and can change rapidly. "Overnight, a further four Australians and one family member also departed the West Bank for Jordan." Australians in need of emergency consular assistance should contact the Australian Government’s 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 (from overseas) or 1300 555 135 (from within Australia).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 25 people supported by the Australian government have now left Gaza

props.alt: an australian flag on a bus

children.content: Australians were greeted at Rafah by officials yesterday
(ABC News)
Two more people supported by the Australian government have been able to leave Gaza, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFA) says.
This brings the total of people helped out of Gaza by the Australian government to
Yesterday it confirmed 20 Australians safely fled the strip, as well as a permanent resident and two family members.
It is not known whether the two who left in the past 24 hours are citizens.
A DFAT spokesperson told the ABC it was still assisting
64 individuals in Gaza
, composed of Australians and their families, who have requested help to depart.
"We continue to engage closely with partners in the region to ensure the remaining Australians in Gaza who wish to leave are able to do so as soon as possible," they said.
"Departures depend on a range of factors, and the situation in Gaza remains highlight challenging and can change rapidly.
"Overnight, a further four Australians and one family member also departed the West Bank for Jordan."

Australians in need of emergency consular assistance should contact the Australian Government’s 24-hour Consular Emergency Centre on +61 2 6261 3305 (from overseas) or 1300 555 135 (from within Australia).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Thailand is in touch with Iran and other governments that can make contact with Hamas, seeking the safe release of nearly two dozen Thai nationals being held hostage by the organisation, according to its foreign minister. Foreign Minister Parnpree Bahiddha-Nukara said Iran, which is close to Hamas, had promised to help with negotiations. At least 23 Thai nationals were among more than 240 people taken hostage when Hamas attacked Israel on October 7. Some 30,000 Thai nationals were working in Israel at the time of the attack. More than 7,000 have since returned home on government evacuation flights. Reporting with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Thailand in talks with Iran and others for Hamas hostages release

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel will return Gazans working inside the country to the besieged Palestinian territory, the government says. "Israel is severing all contact with Gaza. There will be no more Palestinian workers from Gaza," the Israeli security cabinet announced in a statement late Thursday. "Those workers from Gaza who were in Israel on the day of the outbreak of the war will be returned to Gaza," it added, without specifying how many people would be sent back. Before the start of the war, Israel had issued work permits to some 18,500 Gazans, according to COGAT, the Israeli defence body responsible for Palestinian civilian affairs. COGAT did not immediately return a request for information on the number of Gazans working inside Israel at the time of the attack on October 7. Reporting with AFP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel says it will return Gazan labourers to the enclave and sever 'all contact'

Before the start of the war, Israel had issued work permits to some
18,500 Gazans,
according to COGAT, the Israeli defence body responsible for Palestinian civilian affairs.
COGAT did not immediately return a request for information on the number of Gazans working inside Israel
at the time of the attack on October 7
Reporting with AFP

image.altText: A blue sleeve with a Victoria Police badge sewn into it, including the motto "Uphold the Right".

items.synopsis: A senior Victorian police officer has been sentenced to almost five years' jail for raping a "vulnerable" junior officer, prompting calls for a fresh focus on "predatory behaviour" by members of the force.

title.children: Senior police officer jailed for rape, sexual assault of junior colleague, sparking new calls for police ombudsman

image.altText: a shirtless tattooed man on his kneeds with hands behind his back

items.synopsis: Hakan Ayik has been on NSW's most-wanted list for more than a decade, suspected of the alleged "supply of large commercial quantities of drugs" and links to the Comancheros bikie gang.

title.children: Phone tracking app leads to dramatic arrest of suspected Australian drug smuggler in Türkiye

image.altText: SA chief health officer Nicola Spurrier addresses a parliamentary committee.

items.synopsis: South Australia's public health chief Nicola Spurrier warns the state is "clearly" at the beginning of a "new wave" of COVID-19, but says the rise is not being driven by the Pirola variant.

title.children: New COVID wave hitting SA and increasing cases — but Pirola variant not to blame

image.altText: Eric Trump wearing a blue suit and a smile as he sits in a courtroom.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump had put his two sons in charge of his real estate empire while he served as US president from 2017 to 2021, but they both say they had no involvement with the documents at the centre of the fraud trial.

title.children: Eric Trump says he wasn't aware of dad's fraudulent financial statements, but emails suggest some involvement

image.altText: A young man takes a mirror selfie

items.synopsis: As 360,000 Israeli reservists flock to join the war effort against Hamas, some returning volunteers and their families have asked why Yair Netanyahu is not among them.

title.children: Benjamin Netanyahu's controversial son did not return home for war. Some Israelis are wondering why

image.altText: Bankman-Fried looks to his right as he wears a suit to face court.

items.synopsis: FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried has been found guilty of defrauding customers of his now-bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange in one of the biggest financial frauds on record.

title.children: Ex-crypto mogul Sam Bankman-Fried convicted of one of the biggest financial frauds on record

image.altText: An older photograph of Denise Govendir in a white and blue shirt

items.synopsis: Denise Govendir was murdered in her Sydney home in 1998 by an alleged unknown man pretending to be a police officer.

title.children: 'Happiness was robbed from her': $1m reward offered over murder of Sydney mother in 1998

image.altText: The Beatles during a photo session in Twickenham, 9 April 1969

items.synopsis: Processing a new song from a band that looms so large is a complex undertaking.

title.children: 'Mixed feelings': Fans weigh in following release of The Beatles' final ever song

image.altText: a woman standing in a pew in a packed church

items.synopsis: The life and legacy of Labor giant Bill Hayden was honoured at a state funeral service in his hometown south-west of Brisbane today.

title.children: Political heavyweights, friends and family come together for 'remarkable' Bill Hayden's state funeral

image.altText: Justice Gregory Geason photographed in court.

items.synopsis: The state's Attorney-General says he is taking the matter "very seriously" and the Chief Justice has asked the judge, whom the ABC understands to be Gregory Geason, to take leave "until further notice".

title.children: Tasmanian Supreme Court judge stood down in relation to 'significant matter'

image.altText: A composite image showing a man in a suit in an office and the exterior of an office with the sign "AMS LAW".

items.synopsis: A suspected Ponzi scheme that has ensnared Melbourne racing identities and a senior AFL figure was offering returns of up to 8 per cent before the sudden death of its alleged mastermind last month.

title.children: Melbourne lawyer's suspected $100 million Ponzi scheme could dwarf Melissa Caddick fraud

image.altText: Two women embrace crying at a funeral in Gaza.

items.synopsis: Palestinians living in Australia mourn the death of loved ones in Gaza while dealing with survivor's guilt, while some warn of a looming mental health crisis.

title.children: 'Treat us like we matter': Palestinian communities struggle to be heard amid rising death toll in Gaza

image.altText: Woman patting dog in hallway of home

items.synopsis: Central Queenslanders are making tens of thousands of dollars by converting their properties to short-term rentals. Experts warn people need to read the fine print before they open their doors.

title.children: $9,000 a week rent was too good for a Queensland homeowner to pass up. But there are risks

image.altText: The back of a women looking down a dark hallway in shadows

items.synopsis: The apparent suicide of a Tasmanian mother of three 13 years ago is being re-examined in an inquest, with the coroner's court hearing the woman's husband had had an affair and was later convicted of fraud.

title.children: 'Happy-go-lucky' mother of three's apparent suicide re-examined 13 years later

image.altText: A woman in a green shirt holding a photo of her late husband

items.synopsis: Widow Julia Evans says she reassured her late husband he was in good hands at the hospital. She now says she was very wrong.

title.children: 'Miss him dreadfully': Family sues Calvary Health Care over death of much-loved father, husband and teacher

image.altText: A screen still from the movie You've Got Mail, of Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan interacting in a bookshop.

items.synopsis: Meg Ryan is making a rom-com comeback. What Happens Later marks her first film in eight years and over a decade since her last romantic comedy. We look back at her impact on the rom-com genre.

title.children: Meg Ryan is back with her first romantic comedy in over a decade: We look back at her impact on the genre

image.altText: Someone holding up a positive covid-9 rat test with the box in the background

items.synopsis: COVID-19 case numbers are tipped to rise before Christmas. Here's the picture across Australia, the latest on booster shots, and changes to reporting of national figures.

title.children: When was your last COVID booster shot? Here's the vaccine advice as the eighth wave approaches

image.altText: A small white platypus with a black tail and bill is photographed in a body of dark water

items.synopsis: A scientist was scouring the waterways of the Northern Tablelands for turtles when she instead made what is believed to be only the 13th sighting of a white platypus in 187 years.

title.children: Rare white platypus named Bloop stuns researchers as genetic abnormality found

image.altText: Trucks stacked with personal goods sit in a border queue as people head back to Afghanistan from Pakistan.

items.synopsis: Pakistan detains and deports Afghans after nationwide searches under a crackdown on undocumented or unregistered foreigners, with aid agencies warning of chaotic and desperate scenes among those returning to Afghanistan.

title.children: Pakistan demolishes homes, raids neighbourhoods under crackdown to force millions of Afghans to leave

image.altText: A family of two adults and two children with blurred faces, holding Australian flags and a toy kangaroo and koala

items.synopsis: The man, his wife and their two young children were among a group of Australians and other foreign nationals who were able to escape Gaza when the Rafah border crossing opened to civilians for the first time.

title.children: 'My heart is torn apart': Adelaide man relieved to escape Gaza but fears for family left behind

image.altText: soldiers advancing in smoke

items.synopsis: Israel's defence force chief of staff says forces are operating in Gaza City after encircling it from several directions, while the US calls for a series of pauses in fighting to allow aid in and foreign nationals out.

title.children: Israel says troops are operating in Gaza City as US presses for pauses in fighting

image.altText: Mariah Carey singing into a microphone on stage with arms held up, wearing a red festive dress

items.synopsis: Pop star Mariah Carey is facing a $31 million lawsuit over her Christmas hit All I Want for Christmas Is You.

title.children: Mariah Carey's Christmas classic draws attention every holiday season. And she's again being sued for it

image.altText: Awkwafina in a long black wig looks annoyed and Sandra Oh with purple highlights looks shocked

items.synopsis: Sandra Oh plays a party girl and Awkwafina plays a nerd to tackle issues of addiction, sibling rivalry and putting up with the people you love in the new film Quiz Lady.

title.children: Quiz Lady, the romping new sister comedy starring Sandra Oh, Awkwafina and Will Ferrell
